content:
Manually re-create the folder structure of your sbcglobal.net account underneath the Thunderbird built-in "Local Folders" account. https://kb.mozillazine.org/Local_Folders

Then copy over messages from your sbcglobal.net account to the "Local Folders" account on a folder by folder basis. Once everything has been copied over you can delete the sbcglobal.net account. Make sure to create a full backup of your Thunderbird profile prior to start messing with it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile

Once done, backup your your profile on a regular basis.
creator: christ1

content:
Please tell me what I should do to avoid that cancellation.

Well, if you want to keep the account that should be pretty obvious. It's stated in the message you received: "Log in to keep your account." https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/mozilla-account-deletion-inactivity

This hasn't got anything to do with your actual email accounts set up in Thunderbird. Even if your Mozilla account expires you wouldn't notice anything in Thunderbird. There may be a greater impact for Firefox, e.g. if you sync your bookmarks to your Mozilla account.

If you don't know what a Mozilla account is all about, then I'm wondering why you did create one in the first place. It certainly didn't get created magically out of the blue.
creator: christ1

content:
Rene Satos said
I can't understand this messsage as I use daily several times the Mozilla products Thunderbird and Firebird. Please dont cancel my account as it would have catastrophic consequences. Please tell me what I should do to avoid that cancellation.

What the Mozilla Accounts are used for https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/access-mozilla-services-firefox-account#w_what-services-can-i-use-with-a-mozilla-account as it is not used with the Thunderbird email client.

Mozilla Accounts was formerly called Firefox Accounts till Nov 2023 as it was changed to reflect on being used for multiple things besides say Firefox Sync.

This support.mozilla.org site uses Mozilla Accounts (since April 14, 2020) and if the email was about this same Mozilla account then by logging into your Mozilla Account here it should now be considered active and should not be deleted.

content:
Is there any possibility to reenter passwords for the exisisting accounts in thunderbird?

Thunderbird will prompt you for a password when it's needed.

Even if I close and open thunderbird again, it just says Thunderbird wasn't able to connect but no window requesting to enter password appears.

So you don't even get to the point where Thunderbird would prompt you for a password. There are multiple potential reasons why not:

  • your Internet connection is not working - can you login to your account via webmail?
  • your account settings are wrong - check with your email provider about the correct settings.
  • your anti-virus software is interfering

What is the exact error message?

What is your anti-virus software?

content: Yes, but it's a little work. - create an export in csv format of current entries in thunderbird addressbook - open this in excel and note the first row. that shows the layout that thunderbird uses - now, rearrange your spreadsheet to match that - you only need the columns that you use and can omit the others - be sure to keep the top row - save the spreadsheet in csv format and then use the tools>import>import a file menu

content: Thank you, Matt. Luckily for me I have Hover as my provider and their phone help is awfully good. Before I got your generous reply I phoned them and in an hour's worth of work found that all my server parameters were wrong, both for the secondary account that had stopped syncing but also for the main account which had no problems. Hover help couldn't tell my how either one was working -- said they shouldn't be -- but directed me to correct the parameters. Somehow that didn't help, so finally they said remove both accounts and install them again (with correct parameters) and that did work, although it took most of an hour to reload all the emails for both accounts. By the way, the wrong parameters that had been working for both accounts for many months were the ones defaulted by Thunderbird, for example, mail.mann.org instead of mail.hover.com and wrong port numbers for both incoming and outgoing mail. So, in the end, I'm completely back up but I never found out how I could have been running for so long with all the wrong parameters. Thank you again for your help. The problem is solved and I'll see if I can find a button to signal that. I'll also be glad to try your help with the activity manager and error console, which I knew nothing about. I really seek out useful information like that.

content:
Search has remained largely unchanged for more than 10 years. SO you and I are starting with way different positions.

Search comes in three "flavours". 1. Global search (CTRL+K) Documented here https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/global-search I just checked the 2014 version of that article, which is the earliest on this site as it was migrated from mozilla support in 2014. It is almost identical. 2. Quick search (Ctrl+Shift+K) Like the global search this feature is documented https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/quick-filter-toolbar also like global search the 2014 version of the acticle appear to be largely the same as is corrently displayed. 3. search messages (ctrl+shift+F) This is Thunderbird's original search and predates global search and the quick filter. It is now the same as it was in Thunderbird versions 1 and 2

I have to wonder if you have message threading turned on and it is the root cause of your confusion. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird#
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
several issues here.

1. Caldav is not part of IMAP and you are connecting to a caldav server not an IMAP one. Despite that being a Cyrus back end, the protocols, and ports, are nothing alike. Caldav is HTTP/HTTPS (webpage) where IMAP is IMAP (email).

2. Thunderbird stores all passwords for calendars separately to IMAP. The exception being oAuth where the token is stored in the password manager and shared between calendar and mail.

3. When a calendar is created, you have to tell Thunderbird that credentials are required.

What I find these days is users who have never been challenged for a password turn off authentication when it fails and they are asked for a password. That approach appears to be used if they do not have the password or the one they supply fails.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thanks for the clarification between IMAP and Caldav.

We have resolved this problem. The problem was caused by a Provider account inside Thunderbird having a username that was blank. The steps to correct the problem are

In Thunderbird go to Account Settings, on bottom left click on Thunderbird Settings Click on "Privacy & Security" and Select "Saved Passwords..." Remove the line with the blank username.

I don't know how this entry was created but I see entries in other Thunderbird instances that are also blank so they are not uncommon. They also don't necessarily cause a problem but when it did the failure was silent on the user's end making this hard to identify. Seeing the log entries on the server was definitive.
